item.title: Old collection of web-based applications.
item.dc:creator: msouden
item.description: This was originally just a link I posted in 2007, but I got curious and dug the original list out of the wayback machine during this site refresh. I have no idea how many of these are still in existence, but cool list. Original Link: http://www.tzunami.com/No-More-Harddrive.php Enterprise CM Cloud
item.content:encoded:

item.title: SaaS, PaaS, and IaaS
item.dc:creator: msouden
item.description: from Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platform_as_a_service#Types PaaS is derived from software as a service (SaaS), and is situated in cloud computing between SaaS and infrastructure as a service (IaaS). SaaS is software hosted in the cloud so that it does not take up hard drive space on the computers of users. IaaS provides virtual hardware from a provider with adjustable scalability. With IaaS, […]
item.content:encoded:
from Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platform_as_a_service#Types

PaaS is derived from software as a service (SaaS), and is situated in cloud computing between SaaS and infrastructure as a service (IaaS). SaaS is software hosted in the cloud so that it does not take up hard drive space on the computers of users. IaaS provides virtual hardware from a provider with adjustable scalability. With IaaS, the user still has to manage the server, whereas with PaaS the server management is done by the provider.

A private PaaS can typically be downloaded and installed either in a company’s on-premises data center, or in a public cloud. Once the software is installed on one or more machines, the private PaaS arranges the application and database components into a single hosting platform.

So, Youtube: Saas . WPEngine: PaaS, and AWS: IaaS

Those are the basics – head over to the link if you want to read about mPaaS, CPaaS, Open PaaS, NaaS, and MBaaS.

item.title: Mac Special Key Symbols
item.dc:creator: msouden
item.description: A table for referencing the unicode for special symbols to get fancy with the icons when theming. It’s liberated from : https://macbiblioblog.blogspot.com/2005/05/special-key-symbols.html Symbol Description Unicode Hex Reference ⎋ Escape U+238B ⇥ Tab forward U+21E5 ⇤ Tab back U+21E4 ⇪ Capslock U+21EA ⇧ Shift U+21E7 ⌃ Control U+2303 ⌥ Option (Alt, Alternative) U+2325  Apple symbol […]
item.content:encoded: A table for referencing the unicode for special symbols to get fancy with the icons when theming. It’s liberated from : https://macbiblioblog.blogspot.com/2005/05/special-key-symbols.html

item.title: Mary Meeks internet and mobile trends slideshow 2012
item.dc:creator: msouden
item.description: Here’s an insightful slideshow from an analyst at Kleiner Perkins on internet and mobile industry trends, ad revenue and penetration of markets. Worth clicking through to see where the trends and growth are. Also, TechCrunch has some good commentary on it here.KPCB Internet Trends 2012
item.content:encoded:
Here’s an insightful slideshow from an analyst at Kleiner Perkins on internet and mobile industry trends, ad revenue and penetration of markets. Worth clicking through to see where the trends and growth are. Also, TechCrunch has some good commentary on it here.
KPCB Internet Trends 2012

item.content:encoded:

Rejection Therapy: The Game You Win by Actively Seeking Out Rejection
Fear of rejection is a powerful motivator—or more accurately, anti-motivator. The sting of rejection is sharp (in fact, it actually causes something more like physical pain), probably because most of …

item.title: MyPermissions is a way to track who can do what.
item.dc:creator: msouden
item.description: Archived: Nice way to ensure you’re showing the proper amount of skin on the interwebs… Reshared post from +Mike Elgan What have you agreed to? This site will show you. If you use Facebook, Twitter, Google, Yahoo, DropBox, Linkedin, Flickr or Instagram, you’ve agreed to allow a lot of companies to do things inside your […]
item.content:encoded:
Archived:

Nice way to ensure you’re showing the proper amount of skin on the interwebs…

Reshared post from +Mike Elgan

What have you agreed to? This site will show you.

If you use Facebook, Twitter, Google, Yahoo, DropBox, Linkedin, Flickr or Instagram, you’ve agreed to allow a lot of companies to do things inside your accounts.

But what?

This site will show you: http://mypermissions.org/

Google+: View post on Google+

item.content:encoded:

Embedded Link

The Shapes of CSS
CSS-Tricks Example. Back Home More Demos. via Ad Packs. The Shapes of CSS. All of the below use only a single HTML element. Any kind of CSS goes, as long as it’s supported in at least one browser….
